Name: Non Ontologial Resource Reuse
Description: refers to taking available non-ontological resources2 (e.g., databases, controlled vocabularies, etc.) for the development of ontologies. Non-Ontological Resource Reuse is defined in [80] as the process of choosing the most suitable non-ontological resources for the development of ontologies.

Name: Non Ontological Resource Reengineering
Description: the process of retrieving and transforming an existing non ontological resource (data bases, controlled vocabularies, etc.) into an ontology.

Name: Ontological Resource Reuse
Description: is defined as the process of using available ontological resources (ontologies, modules, statements, or ontology design patterns) in the solution of different problems (e.g., the development of different ontology-based applications, the activity of ontology aligning (as background knowledge), etc.). We distinguish between: ontology reuse, ontology module reuse, ontology statement reuse, and ontology design pattern reuse

Name: Ontology Reuse
Description: the process of using ontologies in the solution of different problems

Name: Ontology Module Reuse
Description: the process of using ontology modules in the solution of different problems

Name: Ontology Statement Reuse
Description: the process of using ontology statements in the solution of different problems

Name: General or Common Ontology Reuse
Description: General or Common Ontology Reuse refers to the process of using general or common ontologies in the solution of different problems.

Name: Domain Ontology Reuse
Description: Domain Ontology Reuse refers to the process of using domain ontologies in the solution of different problems.

Name: Ontology Mapping or Aligning
Description: the activity of finding the correspondences between two or more ontologies and storing/exploiting them. A synonym for this activity is Ontology Mapping.

Name: Ontology Annotation
Description: the activity of enriching the ontology with additional information, e.g. metadata or comments.

Name: Ontology Assessment
Description: the activity of checking an ontology against user requirements, such as usability, usefulness, abstraction, quality, etc.

Name: Ontology Comparison
Description: the activity of finding differences between two or more ontologies or between two or more ontology modules.

Name: Ontology Conceptualization
Description: the activity of organizing and structuring the information (data, knowledge, etc.), obtained during the acquisition process, into meaningful models at the knowledge level according to the ontology specification document. This activity is independent of the way in which the ontology implementation will be carried out.

Name: Ontology Configuration Management
Description: the activity of recording all the versions of the documentation, software and ontology code, and of controling the changes

Name: Control
Description: the activity of guaranteeing that scheduled activities in the ontology development process are completed in the manner intended to be performed.

Name: Ontology Customization
Description: the activity of adapting an ontology to a specific user's needs.

Name: Ontology Diagnosis
Description: the activity of identifying parts of the ontology directly responsible for incorrectness and incompleteness. Ontology diagnosis is triggered by ontology validation.

Name: Ontology Documentation
Description: the collection of documents and explanatory comments generated during the entire ontology building process. Note: Examples of documents external to the implemented ontology include ontology specification documents, sources used for acquiring knowledge, ontology conceptualization document, design and decision criteria, ontological commitments, etc.

Name: Ontology Elicitation
Description: a knowledge acquisition activity in which conceptual structures (e.g. T-Box) and their instances (e.g. A-Box) are acquired from domain experts.

Name: Ontology Enrichment
Description: the activity of extending an ontology with new conceptual structures (e.g., concepts, roles, axioms, etc.).

Name: Ontology Environment Study
Description: the activity of analyzing the environment in which the ontology is going to be developed.

Name: Ontology Evaluation
Description: Ontology evaluation refers to the activity of checking the technical quality of an ontology against a frame of reference.

Name: Ontology Evolution
Description: the activity of facilitating the modification of an ontology by preserving its consistency.

Name: Ontology Extension
Description: an ontology enrichment activity for stretching the ontology in width.

Name: Ontology Feasibility Study
Description: the activity of answering questions like: is it possible to build the ontology? is it suitable to build the ontology?, etc.

Name: Ontology Formalization
Description: the transformation of a conceptual model into a formal or semi-computable model according to a knowledge representation paradigm (e.g., description logics, frames, rules, etc.).

Name: Ontology Forward Engineering
Description: the activity of outputting a new implementation of the ontology on the basis of the new conceptual model.

Name: Ontology Implementation
Description: the activity of generating computable models according to the syntax of a formal representation language (e.g. RDF(s), OWL, FLogic, etc.).

Name: Ontology Integration
Description: the activity of including one ontology in another ontology.

Name: Knowledge Acquisition for Ontologies
Description: activities for capturing knowledge (e.g., T-Box and A-Box) from a variety of sources (e.g., documents, experts, data bases, etc.). We can distinguish between: Ontology Elicitation, Ontology Learning and Ontology Population.

Name: Ontology Learning
Description: Ontology Learning is a knowledge acquisition activity that relies on (semi-) automatic methods to transform unstructured (e.g. corpora), semi-structured (e.g. folksonomies, html pages, etc.) and structured data sources (e.g. data bases) into conceptual structures (e.g. T-Box).

Name: Ontology Localization
Description: the adaption of an ontology to a particular language and culsture.

Name: Ontology Matching
Description: the activity of finding or discovering relationships or correspondences beetween entities of different ontologies or ontology modules. Note: Ontology matching can be seen as the first stage of Ontology Aligning.

Name: Ontology Merging
Description: the activity of creating a new ontology or ontology module from two or more, possibly overlapping, source ontologies or ontology modules.

Name: Ontology Modification
Description: the activity of changing the ontology, without considering the consistency.

Name: Ontology Modularization
Description: the activity of identifying one or more modules in an ontology with the purpose of supporting reuse or maintenance. Note: We can make distinctions between: Ontology Module Extraction and Ontology Partitioning.

Name: Ontology Module Extraction
Description: the activity of obtaining from an ontology concrete modules to be used for a particular pupose (e.g. to contain a particular sub-vocabulary of the original ontology).

Name: Ontology Partitioning
Description: the activity of dividing an ontology into a set of (not necessary disjoint) modules that together form an ontology and that can be treated separately.

Name: Ontology Population
Description: a knowledge acquisition activity that relies on (semi-) automatic methods to transform unstructured (e.g. corpora), semi-structured (e.g. folksonomies, html pages, etc.) and structured data sources (e.g. data bases) into instance data (e.g. A-Box).

Name: Ontology Pruning
Description: the activity of discarding conceptual structures (e.g., part of T-Box) of a given ontology that are not or no longer relevant. Note: Pruning is mostly used in combination with ontology learning methods to discard potentially irrelevant learned concepts/relations.

Name: Ontology Quality Assurance
Description: the activity of assuring that the quality of each and every process carried out and product built (ontology, software and documentation) is satisfactory.

Name: Ontology Reengineering
Description: the process of retrieving and transforming a conceptual model of an existing and implemented ontology into a new, more correct and more complete conceptual model which is reimlemented.

Name: Ontology Restructuring
Description: the activity of correcting and reorganizing the knowledge contained in an initial conceptual model, and detecting missing knowledge. Note: This process contains two phases: analysis and synthesis. The ''analysis phase goal'' is to evaluate the ontology technically, that is, to check that the hierarchy of the ontology and its classes, instances, relations and functions are complete (contain all the definitions required for the domain of chemical substances), consistent (there are no contradictions in the ontology and with respect to the knowledge sources used), concise (there are no explicit and implicit redundancies) and syntactically correct. The ''synthesis phase'' seeks to correct the ontology after the analysis phase and document any changes made.

Name: Ontology Repair
Description: the activity of resolving errors (incompleteness, incorrecteness) in the ontology and it is triggered by ontology diagnosis.

Name: Ontology Reverse Engineering
Description: The activity of outputting a possible conceptual model on the basis of the code in which the ontology is implemented.

Name: Scheduling
Description: The activity of identifying the tasks to be performed during the ontology development, their arrangement, and the time and resources needed for their completion.

Name: Ontology Search
Description: The activity of finding candidate ontologies or ontology modules to be reused

Name: Ontology Selection
Description: The activity of choosing the most suitable ontologies or among those available in an ontology repository or library, for a concrete domain of interest and associated tasks.

Name: Ontology Specialization
Description: an ontology enrichment activity for extending the ontology in depth.

Name: Ontology Specification
Description: The activity of collecting the requirements that the ontology should fulfill, e.g. reasons to build the ontology, target group, intended uses, possibly reached through a consensus process.

Name: Ontology Summarization
Description: the activity of providing an abstract or summary of the ontology content. Note: The summary can include, for example, a couple of top levels in the ontology class hierarchy (perhaps a graphical representation of these top-level concepts and links between them).

Name: Ontology Translation
Description: the activity of changing the representation formalism or language of an ontology from one to another. Note: Ontology Translation can be part of an ontology reengineering process.

Name: Ontology Update
Description: minor changes carried out in an ontology that could not be considered an upgrade.

Name: Ontology Upgrade
Description: the activity of replacing an existing ontology with a new version.

Name: Ontology Validation
Description: the ontology evaluation that compares the meaning of the ontology definitions against the intended model of the world aiming to conceptualize. Note: It answers the question: Are you producing the right ontology?.

Name: Ontology Verification
Description: the ontology evaluation which compares the ontology against the ontology specification document (ontology requirements and competency questions), thus ensuring that the ontology is built correctly (in compliance with the ontology specification). Note: It answers the question: Are you producing the ontology right?.

Name: Ontology Versioning
Description: the activity of handling ontology changes by creating and managing different versions of the ontology [54].

Name: Ontology Design Pattern Reuse
Description: the activity of using ontology design patterns in the solution of different modelling problems during the development of new ontologies

Name: Ontology Module Assessment
Description: The goal of ontology module assessment is to find out which ontology modules, from the set of candidate ontology modules, are useful for the development of the ontology network.

Name: Ontology Module Selection
Description: The objective of this activity is to find out which ontology modules are the most suitable for the development of the ontology network.

Name: Ontology Module Integration
Description: The objective of this activity is to integrate the ontology modules selected in the ontology network being developed.

Name: Domain Ontology Search
Description: The objective of this activity is to search in libraries, repositories and registries for candidate domain ontologies that could satisfy the needs of the ontology network being developed.

Name: Domain Ontology Assessment
Description: The objective of this activity is to find out if the set of candidate domain ontologies are useful for the development of the ontology network.

Name: Domain Ontology Selection
Description: The objective of this activity is to find out which domain ontologies are the most suitable for the development of the ontology network.

Name: Domain Ontology Integration
Description: The objective of this activity is to integrate the selected domain ontologies in the ontology network being developed.

Name: Ontology Statement Search
Description: The goal of this activity is to search the internet for candidate ontology statements that could satisfy the ontological needs in a particular case

Name: Ontology Statement Assessment
Description: The goal of this activity is to decide if a concrete ontology statement is useful or not for the ontology network being developed.

Name: Ontology Statement Selection
Description: The goal of this activity is to decide between the useful ontology statements which ones are the best or most convenient for the ontology network being developed.

Name: Ontology Statement Integration
Description: The goal of this activity is to decide how the selected ontology statements will be integrated in the ontology network being developed

Name: Check local inconsistencies
Description: The goal of this activity is to check for local inconsistencies in the ontology network.

Name: Common Ontology Selection
Description: The most important definitions and axioms (e.g. transitivity of part of in mereology), and those that distinguish the different variants of the support theory should be identified.

Name: Common Ontology Customization
Description: Customize the selected common ontology according to the needs of the host ontology.

Name: Common Ontology Integration
Description: The customized common ontology is included in the destination ontology, and the global result is evaluated again, whereas the host ontology is the ontology network which is being developed.

Name: Carry out the Background Study on the Support Theory
Description: The ontology development team should study the theory (and its variants) that supports the type of common ontology to be reused

Name: Identify the most significant definitions and axioms of the support theory
Description: The most important definitions and axioms (e.g. transitivity of part of in mereology), and those that distinguish the different variants of the support theory should be identified

Name: Search for common ontologies supported by the theory
Description: The ontology development team should search for ontologies implemented in a computable language

Name: Build the comparative study
Description: It is assumed that each row represents the set of definitions (or axioms) identified in activity 2, and each column, the ontologies found in activity 3

Name: Non-ontological resource search
Description: The goal of the activity is to search non-ontological resources from highly reliable Web sites, domain-related sites and resources within organizations.

Name: Non-ontological resource assessment
Description: The goal of this activity is to assess the set of candidate non-ontological resources

Name: Lexical Entries Extraction
Description: The goal of this task is to extract the lexical entries of the non ontological resources.

Name: Non-ontological Precision Calculation
Description: The goal of this task is to calculate the precision of the non ontological resources.

Name: Non-ontological Coverage Calculation
Description: The goal of this task is to calculate the coverage of the non ontological resources

Name: Non-ontological Consensus Evaluation
Description: The goal of this task is to evaluate the consensus of the non ontological resources.

Name: Non-ontological Assessment Table Creation
Description: The goal of this task is to create an assessment table of the non ontological resources.

Name: Non-ontological Quality Criteria Extraction
Description: The goal of this task is to extract quality-related criteria of the non ontological resources.

Name: Non-ontological Resource Selection
Description: The goal of this activity is to select the most appropriate non ontological resources

Name: Non-ontological Resource Reverse Reengineering
Description: The goal of this activity is to analyze a NOR to identify its underlying components and create representations of the resource at the different levels of abstraction (design, requirements and conceptual)

Name: Non-ontological Resource Documentation Gathering
Description: The goal of this task is to search and compile all the available documentation about the non ontological resource including purpose, components; data model and implementation details.

Name: Non-ontological Resource Schema Extraction
Description: The goal of this task is to identify the non ontological resource schema including the conceptual components and their relationships.

Name: Non-ontological Resource Data Model Extraction
Description: The goal of this task is to find out how the non ontological resource schema and its content are represented in the data model.

Name: Non-ontological Resource Transformation
Description: The goal of this activity is to generate a conceptual model from the NOR

Name: Non-ontological Resource Reengineering Pattern Search
Description: The goal of this task is to find out if there is any applicable pattern for reengineering non ontological resources useful to transform the non ontological resource into a conceptual model.

Name: Non-ontological Resource Reengineering Pattern Transformation
Description: The goal of this task is to apply the reengineering pattern obtained in task 4 to transform the non ontological resource into a conceptual model

Name: Non-ontological Resource Reengineering Ad-hoc Transformation
Description: The goal of this task is to establish an ad-hoc procedure to map the non ontological resource into a conceptual model, just in case a suitable pattern for reengineering was not found

Name: Ontology Design Patterns Requirements Identification
Description: The objective of this task is to identify which requirement(s), from the ORSD, can be addressed by ontology design pattern reuse.

Name: Ontology Design Patterns Identification
Description: The goal of this task is to identify as many patterns, or rather pattern catalogues, as possible that could help in solving the modelling issues proposed by the requirements selected in the previous task.

Name: Ontology Design Patterns Requirements Problem Division
Description: The goal of this task is to prepare the set of modeling problems posed by the requirements for matching to the set of available patterns.

Name: Ontology Design Patterns Problem Matching
Description: The goal of this task is to identify which patterns are able to solve which parts of the selected subproblem, if any.

Name: Ontology Design Patterns Selection
Description: The goal of this task is to select a set of patterns to reuse based on the results of the matching done in the previous task

Name: Ontology Design Patterns Selection Reuse
Description: The goal of this task is to reuse the selected patterns and compose them.

Name: Ontology Design Patterns Selection Evaluation
Description: The goal of this task is to test the solution with respect to the selected partial problem at hand and to ensure that it really solves this problem in a correct way

Name: Ontology Design Patterns Integration
Description: The goal of this task is to integrate the solutions to the partial problems solved by the previous iterations, or by the parallel teams working on different sub-problems.
